The cool thing about this book is that it's an object you have to interact with.
You can't just - it's not a passive experience, like an iPad or a TV show.
You know, you put that down in front of a kid, and they just - you hope they are quiet during dinner.
This is a book - it's a shared experience.
It is.
It's awesome.
Adam Rubin, he is the author of the new book ""High Five."" The illustrations are done by Daniel Salmieri.
Adam, it was such a pleasure.
Thank you so much for talking with us.
I wish I could do, like, a - oh, I could just air - no, that's lame, to air five you?

Pure joy?

No-look high-five.

No, it's so true.
From the studios of NPR West, this is Day to Day.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
Today, oil prices are hovering around $130 a barrel.
And tomorrow the Senate Judiciary Committee will be asking oil company executives what they can do about rising gas prices.
All the presidential candidates talk a lot about energy independence.
That means relying on our own resources for energy, and weaning ourselves off foreign oil.
Proponents say achieving independence will end our reliance on unfriendly governments; it will stabilize energy costs and clean up our environment.
Well, not everyone agrees with that premise.
Energy writer Robert Bryce is managing editor of the Energy Tribune and a contributor to the Texas Observer.
His new book is ""Gusher of Lies: The Dangerous Delusions of Energy Independence."" Robert Bryce, welcome to Day to Day.
Dangerous delusions?
Hey, thanks very much.
Hmm.
Joe(ph) is on the line.
Joe calling is from Ludlow, Kentucky.
Indeed it is, Alex.
It's a dangerous delusion to believe that the U.S., the world's single biggest energy consumer, can be independent of the world's single biggest business, the $5-trillion-a-year global energy sector.
It's idiotic.
You know that Congress passed an energy independence act last year?
I do yes, in December, the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007.
It achieved neither energy independence nor energy security, as far as I can tell.
Well, this is a process, you know.
This is something that we are seeking to achieve as a nation.
This is a goal that we have set for ourselves.
Well, have we, though?
Richard Nixon talked about it in 1974.
He promised it by 1980.
Gerald Ford talked about it and promised it would happen in 10 years.
Look, this is a delusion because the global market for energy products of all kinds is completely integrated.
Last year alone, the U.S.
purchased oil or oil products from 90 different countries.
That's in 2007, according to the Energy Information Administration.
The U.S.
exported oil or oil products to 73 countries last year.
The fact is, it's a global market whether we're talking about iPods, fresh flowers, bottled water, beer, or crude oil and gasoline.
We need to accept the fact that we live in an interdependent world.
And what you're saying is we can't just stop buying oil from the people we don't like because it's all essentially one big oil pool out there, and if we don't buy it, someone else will.
Exactly.
The fact is, again, according to the EIA, there are 173 countries in the world - out of 204 countries and territories they track, 173 are net oil importers.
We could drop out of the oil market tomorrow and those 172 other countries would continue buying oil from the lowest cost producer.
Again, it's an integrated market.
Robert, there's been a lot of anxiety over the last year about rising oil prices, right?
Sure.
Doesn't this seem like a crisis of some sort?
Well, I think a crisis would be if there were no supply.
Yes, prices are high, and prices are higher than people want to pay.
But let's also put that in perspective.
I wrote a piece that was published last week in Slate saying that $4 gasoline is cheap - and it is when you look at it in a historical perspective.
Back in the early 1920s, on an inflation-adjusted basis, gasoline prices were over $3.10.
So we are paying slightly more that than today.
Why do we believe that we should pay less for our gasoline than our grandparents or great-grandparents did?
In your book you say, look, we're stuck with oil.
We're going to be an oil dependent economy for the next 40, 50 years.
Is there really nothing we can do to significantly lessen our dependence on that?
I think there are certain things we can do to reduce our oil consumption, but you can't use ethanol in a jet airplane.
You can't use it to run diesel trucks.
The fact is that it's taken us over a century to get where we are with the fossil fuels that we use, whether that's coal or petroleum.
And it's going to take us decades to move away into something else.

And we are not going to move to something else, whatever that is, whether it's a new type of motor fuel, whether it's electric cars or something else, unless or until those alternatives or renewables become cheaper, cleaner, more convenient than what we're using now.
Robert Bryce is managing editor of Energy Tribune.
His new book is ""Gusher of Lies: The Dangerous Delusions of Energy Independence."" He spoke with us from Austin, Texas.
Robert, thank you.
Thank you, Alex.
The green tech sector is getting more crowded every week with companies promising that cheaper, cleaner and more convenient energy alternative Robert Bryce talked about.
One of them is Amyris Biotechnologies in Emeryville, California.
Day to Day's Alex Cohen has more.
